wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the core goals and architecture of the local-deep-research project. Explain its purpose as an AI-powered research assistant that performs iterative, citation-aware deep research using multiple LLMs and search engines. Document the high-level system architecture including the web interface, backend services, database layer, and integration points. Describe key design patterns such as Strategy and Factory patterns used in research strategy selection and instantiation. Illustrate component relationships between the search system, LLM providers, search engines, and analytics modules. Include data flow diagrams showing how user queries are processed through query decomposition, parallel search execution, evidence evaluation, and report generation. Provide context for both beginners (explaining RAG concepts, iterative research) and experienced developers (discussing per-user encrypted databases, real-time WebSocket updates). Highlight privacy-preserving features like SQLCipher encryption and zero-knowledge architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Research Modes
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this section covering the four primary research modes: Quick Summary, Detailed Research, Report Generation, and Document Analysis. Explain the purpose, implementation, and optimal use cases for each mode. Document how the search system factory selects appropriate strategies based on the selected mode. Include configuration options, expected output formats, and performance characteristics for each mode. Provide practical examples from the codebase showing how users can invoke each mode through the web interface or programmatic API. Address common issues such as context overflow in Detailed Research mode and citation handling in Report Generation mode. Include guidance on when to use each mode based on query complexity and desired output depth.

wiki_catalogs.name: REST API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive REST API documentation for the local-deep-research system. Document all endpoints including their HTTP methods, URL patterns, request and response schemas, query parameters, and status codes. Detail authentication requirements and security considerations for each endpoint. Cover core functionality such as initiating research tasks, retrieving research results, managing settings, accessing history, and obtaining metrics data. Include detailed examples for each endpoint showing sample requests and responses. Document error handling patterns, rate limiting behavior, and versioning strategy. Provide guidance on proper request formatting, parameter validation, and response parsing. Address common integration issues and performance optimization techniques for efficient API consumption.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Variables
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on environment variable configuration. Explain the purpose and usage of each environment variable category including security settings (ENCRYPTION_KEY, SECURITY_LEVEL), database configuration (DATABASE_URL, SQLCIPHER_PASSWORD), API keys (OPENAI_API_KEY, ANTHROPIC_API_KEY), and performance tuning (MAX_WORKERS, THREAD_TIMEOUT). Document how environment variables are registered, validated, and prioritized through the env_registry system. Provide examples of .env file configurations for different deployment scenarios. Detail the bootstrap process that initializes environment definitions and the role of the env_settings manager in runtime configuration. Include security best practices for handling sensitive credentials and environment isolation between development, testing, and production environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Docker Deployment
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive Docker deployment documentation for the local-deep-research system. Detail the Dockerfile structure, including base image selection, dependency installation, and multi-stage build considerations. Provide complete docker-compose.yml configuration examples with proper service definitions, environment variables, volume mounts for persistent data storage, and network configuration. Explain the purpose and functionality of the entry point scripts (ldr_entrypoint.sh and ollama_entrypoint.sh) in container initialization and service orchestration. Document image building process, container runtime configuration, and resource allocation for optimal performance. Include security best practices for container deployment, such as user permissions, read-only filesystems, and secret management. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common Docker deployment issues like volume mounting problems, network connectivity, and permission errors. Address production considerations including logging strategies, health checks, and backup procedures for containerized deployments.

Provide practical examples showing integration with LangChain pipelines and chains. Detail the differences between programmatic and web interface usage patterns. Explain the serialization and deserialization process for maintaining state across sessions. Include troubleshooting guidance for common integration issues such as schema mismatches, performance bottlenecks, and authentication problems. Cover the testing strategy for retriever integration and provide code examples from the test suite.

wiki_catalogs.name: Basic Research Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for basic research examples that introduce new users to the core functionality of the local-deep-research system. Explain step-by-step execution of simple queries using both programmatic and HTTP APIs. Document the structure of minimal working examples, including environment setup, client initialization, and result interpretation. Include complete code snippets with explanations of key parameters and function calls. Demonstrate basic research workflows from query submission to result retrieval. Use real example topics (e.g., financial crisis, medical topics) to illustrate practical usage. Address common beginner mistakes and provide troubleshooting tips for initial setup issues. Make content accessible to developers with minimal AI/LLM experience while establishing a foundation for more advanced topics.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Issues
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for configuration troubleshooting. Thoroughly explain common configuration problems including API key setup for OpenAI and other LLM providers, environment variable misconfigurations, and search engine credential issues. Document the correct format and placement of configuration values in both environment variables and settings files. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing proper configuration patterns. Explain relationships between configuration files and runtime behavior. Address common issues like missing API keys, incorrect model names, and invalid endpoints with their solutions. Provide step-by-step debugging guidance for configuration validation, including using the show_env_vars.py example script. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Glossary of Terms
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create a comprehensive glossary of key technical terms used in the local-deep-research project. Define concepts such as RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), iterative research, constrained search, dual confidence verification, citation handling, research strategies (e.g., adaptive decomposition, evidence-based, parallel), and query decomposition. Explain the meaning of terms like LLM-driven modular strategy, follow-up contextual reasoning, and cross-engine filtering. Include definitions for system components like search engines, retrievers, citation handlers, and knowledge bases. Provide clear, concise explanations with examples from the codebase where applicable. Ensure terminology matches exactly with the project's codebase vocabulary and use consistent naming conventions from the source code.

Include guidance on optimal use cases like fact-checking or simple informational queries, and contrast with when more advanced modes should be used instead.

Provide guidance on overriding defaults through environment variables and custom configuration files. Include examples of production-ready configuration profiles for different deployment scenarios. Address performance optimization through caching strategies, database connection pooling, and resource limits. Document configuration validation and error recovery mechanisms.

wiki_catalogs.name: Research Subscriptions and Scheduling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for research subscription functionality and automated scheduling. Explain the subscription lifecycle from creation through periodic execution to result delivery. Document the subscription types (search-based and topic-based) and their configuration options including refresh intervals, query parameters, and research modes. Cover the integration with the notification system for alerts when new results are available. Detail the scheduler architecture that manages subscription timing and execution priorities. Explain the process of creating subscriptions through the web interface, including the subscription form fields for query, name, refresh frequency, and advanced settings. Provide examples of using subscriptions for monitoring breaking news, tracking research topics, and automated market analysis. Include guidance on managing subscriptions, viewing execution history, and troubleshooting failed runs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Analytics Dashboard Usage
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for analytics dashboard usage that helps users interpret system metrics and performance data. Explain the implementation details of the metrics tracking system, including data collection, storage, and visualization components. Document the various metrics available in the dashboard such as research duration, token usage, cost calculations, and success rates. Provide guidance on interpreting charts and graphs in the metrics interface, including cost analytics, rate limiting, and performance trends. Cover the use of multi_benchmark_speed_demo.py to generate comparative performance data. Explain how to use analytics to identify optimization opportunities and troubleshoot performance issues. Include examples of extracting and analyzing metrics programmatically through the API. Address privacy considerations and data retention policies for analytics information.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Issues
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for database troubleshooting. Thoroughly explain implementation details of the database system including SQLCipher encryption, schema management, and connection handling. Document common database problems such as initialization failures, schema migration issues, and connection pooling errors. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase showing proper database setup and common failure points. Explain relationships between the database layer and other components like research storage and user settings. Address issues like corrupted databases, missing tables, and encryption key problems with their solutions. Provide guidance on database recovery procedures and schema verification. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Release Notes and Migration Guides
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive documentation for version management in the local-deep-research project. Include detailed release notes for significant versions (0.2.0, 0.4.0) documenting new features, improvements, and breaking changes. Create step-by-step migration guides for upgrading between major versions, with specific instructions for configuration changes, database migrations, and API updates. Document the release process outlined in RELEASE_GUIDE.md, including versioning strategy, testing requirements, and deployment procedures. Highlight critical changes that require user action, such as deprecated features, configuration file modifications, and security updates. Provide examples of migration scenarios and troubleshooting tips for common upgrade issues. Ensure all information is accurate and reflects the actual changes documented in the release notes and migration guide.

wiki_catalogs.name: Recursive Decomposition Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Recursive Decomposition Strategy, which breaks complex queries into hierarchical sub-questions for systematic resolution. Explain the tree-based decomposition logic and traversal algorithm. Document integration with decomposition_question and query_generation modules for dynamic sub-question creation. Include examples of how atomic_fact_question and standard_question components structure the research hierarchy. Address termination conditions, result synthesis, and error propagation in deep trees. Discuss use cases for highly complex, multi-domain inquiries and provide guidance on managing computational overhead.

wiki_catalogs.name: News Sources
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for news search sources including The Guardian and Wikinews. Explain the real-time news indexing capabilities, article metadata extraction, and publication date filtering. Document API authentication requirements, query construction for news topics, and result sorting by relevance or date. Cover integration with the news subscription system and breaking news detection. Include configuration options for news source prioritization, language filtering, and credibility assessment. Address rate limiting for high-frequency news monitoring and handling of paywalled content from commercial news providers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Error Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the API error handling patterns and response formats. Document the standard error response structure with status, message, and error details. Explain the different error types including validation errors, authentication errors, resource not found errors, and internal server errors. Detail the HTTP status codes used for different error conditions and the circumstances under which each is returned. Document the error logging mechanism and how errors are reported in the system. Include examples of error responses for common failure scenarios such as missing required parameters, authentication failures, and server-side exceptions. Explain the client-side error handling recommendations and retry strategies. Address the security considerations in error responses to avoid information disclosure while providing sufficient detail for debugging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Local and Private Search Engines
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for implementing local search engines. Thoroughly explain the architecture for Elasticsearch, Paperless, and local file system integrations, focusing on privacy-preserving search capabilities. Document the setup process for self-hosted search infrastructure, including connection configuration, authentication, and index management. Detail the implementation of the local search engine base class and how it handles document retrieval from private repositories. Cover specialized features like full-text PDF search, metadata extraction from scanned documents, and integration with document management systems. Include guidance on securing local search endpoints, managing access controls, and optimizing search performance for large local document collections. Provide examples from the Elasticsearch implementation and Paperless integration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deletion System and Data Integrity
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the deletion system that ensures data integrity during document and collection removal. Explain the cascade deletion pattern implemented through the cascade_helper utility and its role in maintaining referential integrity. Document the three-level deletion service architecture (document, collection, bulk) and their respective APIs. Describe the safety mechanisms like confirmation dialogs and the ability to recover recently deleted items. Cover the cleanup of associated resources such as PDF files, database records, and index entries during deletion. Provide examples of different deletion scenarios and their impact on related data. Explain the integration with the notification system to inform users of deletion results and any errors encountered during the process.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the notification security model. Explain the zero-knowledge architecture where notification service URLs are encrypted with AES-256 using keys derived from user passwords. Document the SSRF prevention measures in NotificationURLValidator that validate service URLs and prevent access to private IP ranges. Describe the security review process for Apprise integration and how only approved notification services are allowed. Explain the URL validation process for callback links in build_notification_url and how external_url settings are sanitized. Cover the retry mechanism with exponential backoff that prevents notification spamming during failures. Include guidance on secure deployment practices and how to audit notification security.

wiki_catalogs.name: NASA ADS Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the NASA Astrophysics Data System (ADS) integration. Explain how the ADS API enables discovery of astronomical and physics literature through a specialized database with extensive indexing of journal articles, conference proceedings, and technical reports. Document the use of ADS-specific query syntax including Boolean operators, fielded searches (e.g., author, title, abstract, object), and bibliographic codes. Detail the extraction of domain-specific metadata such as astronomical objects, observing facilities, data availability links, and citation networks within astrophysics. Describe integration with the citation formatter for AAS and IOP style references and the PDF downloader for accessing full-text documents. Cover configuration options like filtering by publication date ranges, data availability, and instrument types. Address authentication requirements via API tokens, rate limiting policies, and best practices for conducting literature reviews in astronomy and space sciences.

wiki_catalogs.name: IONOS Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for configuring IONOS as a cloud LLM provider. Document the required configuration parameters including API key, base URL, and model identifiers. Explain how to set up authentication through environment variables (IONOS_API_KEY) and JSON configuration files. Detail the implementation in ionos.py including how it extends the base provider class and handles IONOS-specific authentication requirements. Cover provider-specific features such as regional endpoints and service-specific headers. Provide examples of advanced configurations including custom base URLs for different IONOS regions and request timeout settings. Include security considerations for API key storage and transmission security when integrating with IONOS AI services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for advanced capabilities that extend the core functionality of the system. Thoroughly explain LangChain retriever integration, including setup, configuration, and usage patterns for enterprise knowledge base applications. Document the custom search engine system, detailing how to implement and register new search engine integrations. Cover custom LLM provider development, explaining the interface requirements and registration process. Describe the notification system architecture, including event types, delivery mechanisms, and template customization using Jinja2. Explain research subscription functionality and automated scheduling. Detail the research library features for document management, RAG capabilities, and PDF processing. Include practical examples from the codebase showing implementation of these advanced features and their integration with the core system.

wiki_catalogs.name: Research Library and Document Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the research library features, including document management, RAG capabilities, and PDF processing. Explain the library architecture with Document, Collection, and DocumentBlob entities and their relationships. Document the PDF storage options (database, file system, or none) and their configuration through settings. Cover the document lifecycle from download and storage to metadata extraction and organization. Detail the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) capabilities that allow using library documents as context for research. Explain the collection system for organizing documents into folders and the sharing options for collaborative research. Describe the download management interface and bulk operations. Provide examples of querying the library by research project, domain, or collection, and show how to use library documents in new research queries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Adaptive Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Adaptive Strategy, which dynamically selects and modifies research approaches based on query analysis and runtime performance. Explain the decision logic in search_system_factory.py that evaluates query characteristics to choose optimal strategies. Document how this strategy monitors intermediate results and switches tactics when confidence thresholds aren't met. Include integration with domain_classifier and constraint_analyzer for context-aware adaptation. Provide examples of adaptive behavior in mixed-domain queries and discuss configuration of adaptation rules and sensitivity settings.

wiki_catalogs.name: Meta and Composite Search Engines
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for implementing meta and composite search engines. Explain the architecture of meta-search systems that aggregate results from multiple underlying engines, including parallel_search_engine, meta_search_engine, and search_engine_collection. Document the result merging algorithms, duplicate detection strategies, and ranking normalization techniques used to combine heterogeneous search results. Detail the implementation of the full_search.py orchestrator that coordinates multiple search strategies. Cover configuration options for defining search engine groups, weighting schemes, and fallback behaviors. Include guidance on performance optimization for parallel execution, error handling when individual engines fail, and result consistency across different search sources. Address challenges in maintaining result relevance when combining specialized and general search engines.

wiki_catalogs.name: API and Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for programmatic notification integration. Document the NotificationManager.send_notification method including parameters for event_type, context, and force flag. Explain how to obtain settings snapshots for thread-safe usage in background tasks. Provide examples of integrating notifications into custom research workflows and follow-up systems. Document the NotificationService.send_event method for direct service access. Include code examples in Python showing how to send notifications from both web request contexts and background worker threads. Cover error handling for RateLimitError and SendError exceptions. Explain how to test notification integration using the test_service method and appropriate mocking strategies for unit tests.

wiki_catalogs.name: XAI Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for configuring XAI as a cloud LLM provider. Document the required configuration parameters including API key, base URL, and model identifiers. Explain how to set up authentication through environment variables (XAI_API_KEY) and JSON configuration files. Cover provider-specific features such as token-based authentication and streaming response handling. Cover production configuration requirements including security hardening, performance tuning, and backup strategies. Address scaling considerations for handling multiple concurrent users and resource-intensive research tasks. Include guidance on monitoring deployed instances and log management. Document the entry point scripts and their role in container initialization. Provide best practices for maintaining deployed instances and performing updates with minimal downtime.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Local Deep Research: Comprehensive Project Overview

## Project Introduction

Local Deep Research (LDR) is an AI-powered research assistant designed for deep, iterative research using multiple LLMs and search engines with proper citations. The system performs systematic research by breaking down complex questions into focused sub-queries, searching multiple sources in parallel, verifying information across sources for accuracy, and creating comprehensive reports with transparent sourcing.

**Core Goals and Objectives:**
- Enable deep, iterative research with multiple LLMs and search engines
- Maintain privacy with local execution and encrypted databases
- Provide transparent research with proper citations and source tracking
- Support both local and cloud-based LLMs for flexible deployment
- Offer comprehensive analytics and benchmarking capabilities

**Target Audience:**
- Researchers and academics
- Students conducting in-depth research
- Professionals requiring accurate information
- Privacy-conscious users
- Enterprises integrating with existing knowledge bases

## Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown

Local Deep Research follows a modular architecture with distinct components handling different aspects of the research process. The system is built primarily in Python with a Flask-based web interface and supports both programmatic and web-based interaction.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Interface] --> B[API Layer]
    B --> C[Search System]
    C --> D[LLM Integration]
    C --> E[Search Engines]
    D --> F[Citation Handling]
    E --> G[Rate Limiting]
    C --> H[Research Strategies]
    H --> I[Advanced Search System]
    I --> J[Constraint Checking]
    I --> K[Candidate Exploration]
    C --> L[Report Generation]
    C --> M[Metrics & Analytics]
```

### Design Patterns

The project employs several key design patterns:

1. **Strategy Pattern**: Multiple research strategies (source-based, focused-iteration, parallel, etc.) can be selected based on the query type and user preferences.

2. **Factory Pattern**: The `search_system_factory.py` creates appropriate search strategies based on configuration.

3. **Registry Pattern**: Global registries for LLMs (`llm_registry.py`) and retrievers (`retriever_registry.py`) allow dynamic registration of components.

4. **Two-Phase Retrieval**: Search engines implement a two-phase approach - first retrieving previews, then fetching full content for relevant results.

5. **Per-User Isolation**: Each user has their own encrypted database, ensuring complete data isolation.

### System Relationships

The core relationship is between the search system, LLM providers, and search engines. The search system coordinates the research process, using LLMs to generate queries and analyze results, while leveraging multiple search engines to gather information from diverse sources.

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Web Interface] --> B[API Layer]
    B --> C[Search System]
    C --> D[LLM Providers]
    C --> E[Search Engines]
    D --> F[Ollama]
    D --> G[OpenAI]
    D --> H[Anthropic]
    D --> I[Google]
    E --> J[SearXNG]
    E --> K[Google PSE]
    E --> L[Tavily]
    E --> M[arXiv]
    E --> N[PubMed]
    C --> O[Database]
    O --> P[Encrypted DB]
    C --> Q[Analytics]
```

### Data Flow

The data flow follows a structured research process from query to final report:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Query] --> B[Query Decomposition]
    B --> C[Search Strategy Selection]
    C --> D[Parallel Search Execution]
    D --> E[Results Filtering]
    E --> F[Content Retrieval]
    F --> G[Information Verification]
    G --> H[Citation Generation]
    H --> I[Report Compilation]
    I --> J[Final Output]
    J --> K[Web Interface]
    J --> L[API Response]
    J --> M[PDF Export]
```

## Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `src/local_deep_research/web/app.py` - Web application entry point
- `src/local_deep_research/api/client.py` - Programmatic API client
- `src/local_deep_research/search_system.py` - Core search system
- `scripts/ldr_entrypoint.sh` - Docker entry point script

### Core Modules
- `src/local_deep_research/advanced_search_system/` - Advanced search algorithms and strategies
- `src/local_deep_research/web_search_engines/` - Search engine integrations
- `src/local_deep_research/llm/` - LLM provider integrations
- `src/local_deep_research/database/` - Database and encryption management
- `src/local_deep_research/settings/` - Configuration management

### Configuration Approach
- Environment variables for deployment configuration
- JSON settings files for default configurations
- Web-based settings interface for user preferences
- Per-user encrypted databases for settings persistence

### External Dependencies
- `pyproject.toml` - Project dependencies specification
- `pdm.lock` - Dependency lock file
- `package.json` - Frontend dependencies

### Integration Points
- REST API for programmatic access
- LangChain retriever integration
- WebSocket for real-time updates
- Cookiecutter for Docker configuration
- Unraid template for server deployment

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[External Systems] --> B[REST API]
    A --> C[LangChain]
    A --> D[WebSocket]
    A --> E[Docker]
    A --> F[Unraid]
    B --> G[Local Deep Research]
    C --> G
    D --> G
    E --> G
    F --> G
    G --> H[Search Engines]
    G --> I[LLM Providers]
    G --> J[Database]
```

## Key Features

### Research Modes
Local Deep Research offers multiple research modes to suit different needs:

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> QuickSummary
    QuickSummary --> DetailedResearch: More depth needed
    DetailedResearch --> ReportGeneration: Formal output required
    ReportGeneration --> DocumentAnalysis: Private documents available
    DocumentAnalysis --> QuickSummary: Return to quick queries
    DetailedResearch --> QuickSummary: Simple answer sufficient
```

### Implementation Highlights

**Advanced Search System**: The core of LDR is its advanced search system that implements multiple research strategies. The system can break down complex questions, search multiple sources in parallel, verify information across sources, and create comprehensive reports.

Sources:
- [search_system.py](src/local_deep_research/search_system.py#L20-L377)

**Multiple Research Strategies**: The system supports various research strategies including source-based, focused-iteration, parallel, rapid, recursive decomposition, and adaptive approaches. Each strategy is designed for different types of queries and research goals.

Sources:
- [search_system_factory.py](src/local_deep_research/search_system_factory.py#L25-L800)

**Privacy-Focused Architecture**: LDR prioritizes user privacy with SQLCipher encryption (AES-256), per-user isolated databases, and zero-knowledge architecture. This ensures that user data remains secure and private.

Sources:
- [encrypted_db.py](src/local_deep_research/database/encrypted_db.py)
- [SQLCIPHER_INSTALL.md](docs/SQLCIPHER_INSTALL.md)

**Flexible LLM Integration**: The system supports both local models (via Ollama) and cloud models (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, etc.). Users can switch between different LLMs based on their needs and preferences.

Sources:
- [llm_registry.py](src/local_deep_research/llm/llm_registry.py)
- [llm_providers](src/local_deep_research/llm/providers/)

**Comprehensive Search Sources**: LDR integrates with a wide range of search sources including academic databases (arXiv, PubMed, Semantic Scholar), general web search (SearXNG, Google), technical sources (GitHub, Elasticsearch), and news sources (The Guardian, Wikinews).

Sources:
- [web_search_engines](src/local_deep_research/web_search_engines/)

**Analytics and Benchmarking**: The system includes built-in analytics to track costs, performance, and usage metrics. It also supports benchmarking to evaluate and optimize configurations.

Sources:
- [BENCHMARKING.md](docs/BENCHMARKING.md)
- [analytics-dashboard.md](docs/analytics-dashboard.md)

### Feature Architecture

The feature architecture demonstrates how different components work together to deliver the research capabilities:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[User Interface] --> B[Research Request]
    B --> C{Research Mode}
    C --> D[Quick Summary]
    C --> E[Detailed Research]
    C --> F[Report Generation]
    C --> G[Document Analysis]
    D --> H[Fast Search Strategy]
    E --> I[Iterative Search Strategy]
    F --> J[Structured Report Strategy]
    G --> K[Private Document Strategy]
    H --> L[LLM Processing]
    I --> L
    J --> L
    K --> L
    L --> M[Search Engines]
    M --> N[Web Sources]
    M --> O[Academic Sources]
    M --> P[Technical Sources]
    M --> Q[News Sources]
    L --> R[Citation Handling]
    R --> S[Source Verification]
    S --> T[Report Generation]
    T --> U[Web Output]
    T --> V[API Response]
    T --> W[PDF Export]
```

The architecture enables Local Deep Research to perform systematic, verifiable research while maintaining transparency about sources and providing users with comprehensive, well-cited reports.
</blog>
